article:
2023 Under-19 Women's T20 World Cup

The 2023 Under-19 Women's T20 World Cup is an international women's cricket tournament that was held in South Africa from January 14 to January 29, 2023. It was the inaugural edition of the Under-19 Women's T20 World Cup, and 16 teams participated in the tournament. 

#Background
The tournament was announced by the International Cricket Council (ICC) in 2020, as part of its plan to expand women's cricket globally. The Under-19 Women's T20 World Cup is part of the ICC's strategy to increase participation and competitiveness in women's cricket, particularly at the youth level. The tournament aims to provide a platform for young cricketers to showcase their skills and compete against the best teams from around the world.

#Qualification
The qualification process for the 2023 Under-19 Women's T20 World Cup was based on the ICC's rankings and a series of regional tournaments. The top 11 teams from the ICC's rankings, as of August 2022, qualified directly for the tournament. The remaining five spots were filled by teams that won regional tournaments in Africa, Americas, Asia, Europe, and Oceania.

#Competition format
The 2023 Under-19 Women's T20 World Cup featured 16 teams that were divided into four groups of four teams each. The teams played each other in a round-robin format, with the top three teams from each group advancing to the Super 6 stage. The Super 6 stage consisted of two groups of six teams each, with the top two teams from each group advancing to the knockout stage. The knockout stage consisted of the semi-finals and the final.

#Squads
Each team was allowed to have a squad of 15 players for the tournament. The teams announced their squads in December 2022 and January 2023.

#Match officials
The ICC appointed a panel of umpires and match referees to officiate the tournament. The umpires were from various countries, and the match referees were experienced officials who had previously officiated in international tournaments.

#Venues
The 2023 Under-19 Women's T20 World Cup was held in South Africa, with matches played at several venues in the country. The main venues were the North West University Oval in Potchefstroom, the Senwes Park in Potchefstroom, and the JB Marks Oval in Potchefstroom.

#Warm-up matches
Before the start of the tournament, the teams played warm-up matches against each other. The warm-up matches were played at various venues in South Africa and were used by the teams to acclimate to the conditions and fine-tune their preparations.

#Group stage
The group stage of the tournament began on January 14, 2023, and ended on January 18, 2023. The teams played each other in a round-robin format, with the top three teams from each group advancing to the Super 6 stage.

##Group A
Group A consisted of Australia, Bangladesh, Sri Lanka, and the United States. Australia won all three of their matches, while Bangladesh and Sri Lanka won two matches each. The United States lost all three of their matches.

##Group B
Group B consisted of England, Pakistan, Rwanda, and Zimbabwe. England won all three of their matches, while Pakistan and Zimbabwe won two matches each. Rwanda lost all three of their matches.

##Group C
Group C consisted of India, Ireland, Scotland, and the West Indies. India won all three of their matches, while the West Indies and Ireland won two matches each. Scotland lost all three of their matches.

##Group D
Group D consisted of New Zealand, Indonesia, South Africa, and the United Arab Emirates. New Zealand and South Africa won three matches each, while the United Arab Emirates won one match. Indonesia lost all three of their matches.

#Fourth-Place play-offs
The teams that finished fourth in each group played each other in the fourth-place play-offs. The matches were played on January 19, 2023, and the winners were the United States, Rwanda, Scotland, and Indonesia.

#Super 6
The Super 6 stage of the tournament began on January 20, 2023, and ended on January 25, 2023. The teams were divided into two groups of six teams each, with the top two teams from each group advancing to the knockout stage.

##Super 6 Group 1
Super 6 Group 1 consisted of Australia, Bangladesh, England, Pakistan, South Africa, and the West Indies. Australia and England won four matches each, while South Africa and the West Indies won three matches each. Bangladesh and Pakistan won two matches each.

##Super 6 Group 2
Super 6 Group 2 consisted of India, Ireland, New Zealand, Sri Lanka, Zimbabwe, and the United Arab Emirates. India won four matches, while New Zealand and Sri Lanka won three matches each. Zimbabwe and Ireland won two matches each, while the United Arab Emirates won one match.

#Knockout stage
The knockout stage of the tournament began on January 27, 2023, and ended on January 29, 2023. The top two teams from each group in the Super 6 stage advanced to the semi-finals.

##Semi-finals
The semi-finals were played on January 27, 2023. Australia played India, while England played South Africa. Australia won by 7 wickets, while England won by 3 runs.

##Final
The final was played on January 29, 2023, between Australia and England. Australia won by 7 wickets, with Rhys McKenna scoring 61 not out.

The top run-scorers in the tournament were:

* Shweta Sehrawat (India) - 297 runs

##Most wickets
The top wicket-takers in the tournament were:

article:
**Jurassic World Dominion**

Jurassic World Dominion is a 2022 American science fiction adventure film directed by Colin Trevorrow, who co-wrote the screenplay with Emily Carmichael. It is the sequel to Jurassic World: Fallen Kingdom (2018) and the sixth installment in the Jurassic Park franchise. The film takes place four years after the events of the previous installment and follows a group of characters as they navigate a world where dinosaurs and humans coexist.

**Plot**

The film takes place in a world where dinosaurs have been released into the wild and are living among humans. The story follows Owen Grady (Chris Pratt), a former Velociraptor trainer who is now living in the wilderness with his partner, Claire Dearing (Bryce Dallas Howard). The two are tasked with rescuing a group of genetically engineered dinosaurs, including a young Velociraptor named Beta, who have been stolen by a group of mercenaries.

Meanwhile, a new threat emerges in the form of a giant locust infestation that is threatening the world's food supply. The locusts are revealed to be genetically engineered by a biotech company called Biosyn, which is led by a wealthy and ruthless CEO named Lewis Dodgson (Campbell Scott). As the story unfolds, Owen and Claire team up with a group of allies, including Dr. Alan Grant (Sam Neill), Dr. Ellie Sattler (Laura Dern), and Dr. Ian Malcolm (Jeff Goldblum), to take down Biosyn and stop the locust infestation.

**Cast**

* Chris Pratt as Owen Grady
* Bryce Dallas Howard as Claire Dearing
* Laura Dern as Dr. Ellie Sattler
* Sam Neill as Dr. Alan Grant
* Jeff Goldblum as Dr. Ian Malcolm
* DeWanda Wise as Kayla Watts
* Mamoudou Athie as Ramsay Cole
* Isabella Sermon as Maisie Lockwood
* Campbell Scott as Lewis Dodgson
* BD Wong as Dr. Henry Wu
* Omar Sy as Barry Sembène
* Justice Smith as Franklin Webb
* Daniella Pineda as Dr. Zia Rodriguez

**Production**

### Development

Jurassic World Dominion was first announced in February 2018, with Colin Trevorrow set to return as director and co-writer. The film's script was written by Trevorrow and Emily Carmichael, who previously worked together on the film Pacific Rim: Uprising.

### Pre-production

Pre-production on the film began in 2019, with Trevorrow and his team working on the script and storyboards. The film's budget was estimated to be around $165 million, although it ultimately ended up costing over $185 million to produce.

### Writing

The film's script was written by Trevorrow and Carmichael, who drew inspiration from the original Jurassic Park novel by Michael Crichton. The story was designed to be a conclusion to the Jurassic World trilogy, and to tie together the various plot threads from the previous two films.

### Casting

The film's cast includes a mix of returning characters from the previous Jurassic World films, as well as some new additions. Chris Pratt and Bryce Dallas Howard reprised their roles as Owen Grady and Claire Dearing, respectively, while Laura Dern, Sam Neill, and Jeff Goldblum returned to their roles as Dr. Ellie Sattler, Dr. Alan Grant, and Dr. Ian Malcolm, respectively.

### Filming

Principal photography on the film began in February 2020, with filming taking place in various locations around the world, including Canada, the United Kingdom, and Malta. The film's cinematography was handled by John Schwartzman, who previously worked on the film Saving Mr. Banks.

#### COVID-19 pandemic

Filming on the film was disrupted by the COVID-19 pandemic, which forced the production team to shut down filming for several months. The film's cast and crew were required to follow strict safety protocols, including wearing masks and undergoing regular testing.

#### Locations and sets

The film's locations included a mix of real-world locations and studio sets. The film's production team built a large studio set in the UK, which was used to film many of the film's interior scenes. The film's exterior scenes were filmed on location in Canada and Malta.

### Creatures on screen

The film features a wide range of dinosaurs and other creatures, including Velociraptors, Tyrannosaurus Rex, and a giant locust infestation. The film's visual effects were handled by Industrial Light & Magic, which used a combination of CGI and practical effects to bring the creatures to life.

### Post-production

Post-production on the film began in 2020, with Trevorrow and his team working on editing the film and adding visual effects. The film's score was composed by Michael Giacchino, who previously worked on the film Up.

**Music**

The film's score was composed by Michael Giacchino, who previously worked on the film Up. The score features a mix of orchestral and choral elements, and incorporates themes from the previous Jurassic World films.

**Marketing**

The film's marketing campaign began in 2020, with the release of a series of trailers and promotional images. The film's title was officially announced in February 2020, along with a release date of June 2022.

**Release**

### Theaters

The film was released in theaters on June 10, 2022, in the United States and the United Kingdom. The film was released in IMAX and 3D formats, as well as standard 2D.

### Home media

The film was released on home media on August 16, 2022, in the United States and the United Kingdom. The film was released on DVD, Blu-ray, and digital formats.

**Reception**

### Box office

The film was a commercial success, grossing over $1 billion at the global box office. The film's opening weekend was the highest-grossing opening weekend of 2022, with the film grossing over $145 million in the United States and the United Kingdom.

### Critical response

The film received mixed reviews from critics, with some praising the film's action sequences and visual effects, while others criticized the film's plot and characters. The film holds a 38% approval rating on Rotten Tomatoes, based on 422 reviews.

### Accolades

The film was nominated for several awards, including a Saturn Award for Best Science Fiction Film and a Visual Effects Society Award for Outstanding Visual Effects in a Visual Effects-Driven Film.

**Future**

The film's ending sets up the possibility for a new trilogy of films, although no official plans have been announced. Trevorrow has stated that he would be interested in returning to the franchise in the future, although no decision has been made.

Ice Hockey at the 2022 Winter Olympics – Men's Tournament

The men's ice hockey tournament at the 2022 Winter Olympics was held in Beijing, China, from February 9 to 20, 2022. The tournament was the 25th edition of the men's ice hockey tournament at the Winter Olympics.

# Venues

The tournament was held at two venues in Beijing: the National Indoor Stadium, which was the primary venue, and the Wukesong Arena. The National Indoor Stadium has a seating capacity of 18,000, while the Wukesong Arena has a seating capacity of 15,000.

# Qualified Teams

Twelve teams qualified for the men's ice hockey tournament at the 2022 Winter Olympics. The teams were:

*  Canada
*  China (host)
*  Czech Republic
*  Denmark
*  Finland
*  Germany
*  Great Britain
*  Latvia
*  Norway
*  ROC (Russian Olympic Committee)
*  Slovakia
*  United States

# Format

The tournament was played in two stages: the preliminary round and the playoff round. In the preliminary round, the 12 teams were divided into three groups of four teams each. Each team played the other teams in their group once, for a total of three games per team. The top two teams from each group, along with the two best third-place teams, advanced to the playoff round.

In the playoff round, the eight teams that advanced from the preliminary round played a single-elimination tournament. The quarterfinals were played between the top two teams from each group and the two best third-place teams. The winners of the quarterfinals advanced to the semifinals, with the winners of the semifinals advancing to the gold medal game. The losers of the semifinals played in the bronze medal game.

# Rosters

Each team was allowed to have a maximum of 25 players on their roster. The teams were required to submit their rosters to the International Olympic Committee (IOC) by February 3, 2022.

## NHL Participation

The National Hockey League (NHL) did not participate in the 2022 Winter Olympics. The NHL had participated in the previous five Winter Olympics, but due to various reasons, including the COVID-19 pandemic and scheduling conflicts, the league decided not to participate in the 2022 tournament.

# Match Officials

The match officials for the tournament were appointed by the International Ice Hockey Federation (IIHF). The officials included referees, linesmen, and video goal judges.

# Preliminary Round

The preliminary round was played from February 9 to 13, 2022. The 12 teams were divided into three groups of four teams each.

## Tiebreak Criteria

In the event of a tie in the standings, the teams were ranked according to the following tiebreak criteria:

* Number of wins

Gheorghe Pintilie

Gheorghe Pintilie was a Romanian communist politician and security chief who played a significant role in the country's communist regime, particularly during the 1940s and 1950s. He is best known for his involvement in the creation and leadership of the Direcția Generală a Securității Poporului (DGSP), Romania's secret police agency, and his implementation of various repressive policies and atrocities during his tenure.

His involvement with the party led to his arrest and imprisonment in 1928, along with several other communist activists. Pintilie spent several years in prison, where he became acquainted with other prominent communist figures, including Gheorghe Gheorghiu-Dej.

## Communist rise

Following his release from prison in 1933, Pintilie continued his involvement with the PCR, gradually rising through the party ranks. In 1944, he became a member of the party's Central Committee, and in 1945, he was appointed as the head of the PCR's organizational department. Pintilie's position within the party allowed him to play a key role in the communist takeover of Romania following World War II.

## DGSP creation

In 1948, Pintilie was appointed as the head of the newly created Direcția Generală a Securității Poporului (DGSP), Romania's secret police agency. article:
Tornado Outbreak of December 12–15, 2022

A devastating tornado outbreak occurred across the southern United States from December 12 to 15, 2022, resulting in significant damage and loss of life. The outbreak affected multiple states, including Louisiana, Texas, Oklahoma, Arkansas, Missouri, and Tennessee. This article provides an overview of the meteorological conditions that led to the outbreak, the confirmed tornadoes that occurred during the event, and the non-tornadic effects and impact of the outbreak.

#Meteorological synopsis

A powerful winter storm system developed over the southern Great Plains on December 11, 2022, and began to move eastward. As the system strengthened, it brought a mass of cold air from Canada, which collided with warm, moist air from the Gulf of Mexico. This clash of air masses created a highly unstable atmosphere, conducive to thunderstorm development. The Storm Prediction Center (SPC) issued a Moderate Risk (4/5) outlook for severe thunderstorms on December 12, which was later upgraded to a High Risk (5/5) for parts of Louisiana, Texas, and Oklahoma.

As the system continued to move eastward, it brought a strong cold front, which swept across the affected areas, producing a long-lived squall line. The combination of strong wind shear, instability, and lift from the cold front created a favorable environment for tornadoes to develop. The SPC continued to issue High Risk outlooks for severe thunderstorms on December 13 and 14, as the system moved into the southeastern United States.

#Confirmed tornadoes

A total of 67 tornadoes were confirmed during the outbreak, with the majority occurring on December 13. The tornadoes were rated on the Enhanced Fujita scale (EF scale), with the strongest being an EF4.

##December 12 event

On December 12, a total of 5 tornadoes were confirmed, all of which occurred in Oklahoma and Texas. The strongest tornado was an EF2, which occurred in Caddo County, Oklahoma, causing significant damage to homes and businesses.

##December 13 event

December 13 was the most active day of the outbreak, with a total of 34 tornadoes confirmed. The tornadoes occurred across Louisiana, Texas, Oklahoma, and Arkansas. The strongest tornado of the day was an EF4, which occurred in Farmerville, Louisiana, causing catastrophic damage and loss of life.

##December 14 event

On December 14, a total of 16 tornadoes were confirmed, all of which occurred in Louisiana, Texas, and Oklahoma. The strongest tornado of the day was an EF3, which occurred in Red River County, Texas, causing significant damage to homes and businesses.

##December 15 event

On December 15, a total of 12 tornadoes were confirmed, all of which occurred in Tennessee, Missouri, and Arkansas. The strongest tornado of the day was an EF2, which occurred in Weakley County, Tennessee, causing significant damage to homes and businesses.

##Farmerville, Louisiana

The Farmerville, Louisiana EF4 tornado was the strongest and deadliest of the outbreak. The tornado touched down at approximately 2:30 PM CST and remained on the ground for approximately 20 miles. The tornado caused catastrophic damage to homes, businesses, and infrastructure, and resulted in 7 fatalities and over 50 injuries.

#Non-tornadic effects

In addition to the tornadoes, the outbreak also produced significant non-tornadic effects, including strong winds, large hail, and flash flooding. The strong winds caused widespread power outages, with over 100,000 households affected. The large hail caused significant damage to crops and vehicles, while the flash flooding caused evacuations and disruptions to transportation.

#Impact

The tornado outbreak had a significant impact on the affected areas, with widespread damage and loss of life. The total damage estimate was over $1 billion, making it one of the costliest tornado outbreaks in U.S. history. The outbreak also caused significant disruptions to transportation, commerce, and daily life.

#See also

* List of tornado outbreaks
* Tornado Alley
* Storm Prediction Center
* Enhanced Fujita scale

#Notes

This article is a summary of the tornado outbreak and is not intended to be a comprehensive or exhaustive account. The information presented is based on available data and may be subject to revision or update.

#References

#External links

* Storm Prediction Center
* National Weather Service
* National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration

article:
Chandrayaan-3
================

Chandrayaan-3 is a lunar mission developed by the Indian Space Research Organisation (ISRO). Launched on July 14, 2023, the mission aims to demonstrate the capability to soft-land on the lunar surface and conduct scientific experiments. Chandrayaan-3 follows the Chandrayaan-1 mission, which was launched in 2008 and included an orbiter and an impactor, and the Chandrayaan-2 mission, which was launched in 2019 and included an orbiter, a lander, and a rover.

History
--------

The Chandrayaan-3 mission was conceived after the partial success of the Chandrayaan-2 mission. Although the Chandrayaan-2 orbiter continues to orbit the Moon and provide valuable scientific data, the lander and rover were lost due to a technical malfunction during the descent phase. ISRO decided to develop a new lander and rover, leveraging the experience and expertise gained from the previous mission. The Chandrayaan-3 mission was formally approved in November 2019, with a planned launch in 2023.

Objectives
----------

The primary objectives of the Chandrayaan-3 mission are:

1. To demonstrate the capability to soft-land on the lunar surface
2. To conduct scientific experiments on the lunar surface
3. To demonstrate the capability to operate a rover on the lunar surface
4. To study the lunar surface composition, geology, and atmosphere

Spacecraft
----------

### Design

The Chandrayaan-3 spacecraft consists of three main components: the propulsion module, the Vikram lander, and the Pragyan rover.

#### Propulsion module

The propulsion module is the main spacecraft that provides the necessary propulsion, power, and communication for the mission. It is equipped with a high-gain antenna for communication with Earth and a propulsion system consisting of a liquid-fueled engine.

#### Vikram lander

The Vikram lander is designed to soft-land on the lunar surface. It is equipped with a descent imaging camera, a laser altimeter, and a terrain relative navigation system to ensure precise landing. The lander is also equipped with a suite of scientific instruments to study the lunar surface composition and geology.

#### Rover Pragyan

The Pragyan rover is a small, six-wheeled rover designed to operate on the lunar surface. It is equipped with a suite of scientific instruments, including an alpha-proton X-ray spectrometer, a laser-induced breakdown spectrometer, and a seismometer. The rover is designed to move at a speed of 1 cm/s and has a power source consisting of solar panels and batteries.

Payloads
--------

### On lander

The Vikram lander carries a suite of scientific instruments, including:

* Descent imaging camera: to capture high-resolution images of the lunar surface during descent
* Laser altimeter: to measure the distance between the lander and the lunar surface
* Terrain relative navigation system: to ensure precise landing
* Seismometer: to measure seismic activity on the lunar surface
* Langmuir probe: to study the lunar surface plasma

### On rover

The Pragyan rover carries a suite of scientific instruments, including:

* Alpha-proton X-ray spectrometer: to study the lunar surface composition
* Laser-induced breakdown spectrometer: to study the lunar surface geology
* Seismometer: to measure seismic activity on the lunar surface

### On the propulsion module

The propulsion module carries a suite of scientific instruments, including:

* High-gain antenna: for communication with Earth
* Propulsion system: consisting of a liquid-fueled engine
* Power source: consisting of solar panels and batteries

Mission profile
--------------

### Launch

The Chandrayaan-3 mission was launched on July 14, 2023, at 02:35 UTC from the Satish Dhawan Space Centre in Sriharikota, India. The launch vehicle used was the LVM3 (GSLV Mk III).

### Orbit

After launch, the spacecraft entered into a highly elliptical orbit around Earth. The orbit was raised through a series of orbit-raising maneuvers, and the spacecraft finally entered into a lunar transfer orbit.

### Landing

The Vikram lander separated from the propulsion module on August 23, 2023, and descended towards the lunar surface. The lander successfully soft-landed on the lunar surface in the south polar region.

### Surface operations

The Pragyan rover was deployed on the lunar surface on August 24, 2023. The rover began its scientific experiments, including studying the lunar surface composition and geology.

### Propulsion module reinserted to orbit around Earth

After the lander and rover were deployed, the propulsion module reinserted into orbit around Earth. The module will continue to orbit Earth for several years, providing communication relay services for future Indian space missions.

### Mission life

The Chandrayaan-3 mission is designed to have a mission life of one year. However, the mission life can be extended based on the performance of the spacecraft and the scientific instruments.

Team
----

The Chandrayaan-3 mission is led by a team of experienced scientists and engineers from ISRO. The team includes:

* Dr. K. Sivan: Chairman, ISRO
* Dr. S. Somanath: Director, Vikram Sarabhai Space Centre
* Dr. M. Annadurai: Director, ISRO Satellite Centre

Funding
-------

The Chandrayaan-3 mission is funded by the Government of India. The total budget for the mission is approximately ₹615 crore (US$77 million).

Results
-------

### Temperature variation

The Chandrayaan-3 mission has provided valuable data on the temperature variation on the lunar surface. The data shows that the temperature on the lunar surface varies from -173°C to 127°C.

### Detection of sulfur

The Chandrayaan-3 mission has detected sulfur on the lunar surface. The detection was made using the alpha-proton X-ray spectrometer on the Pragyan rover.

### Plasma measurement

The Chandrayaan-3 mission has measured the plasma density on the lunar surface. The measurement was made using the Langmuir probe on the Vikram lander.

### Seismic measurements

The Chandrayaan-3 mission has made seismic measurements on the lunar surface. The measurements were made using the seismometer on the Pragyan rover.

Domestic reactions
------------------

The Chandrayaan-3 mission has received widespread attention and admiration in India. The mission has been hailed as a major achievement for the Indian space program.

International reactions
----------------------

The Chandrayaan-3 mission has received international attention and recognition. The mission has been praised by space agencies around the world, including NASA and the European Space Agency.

Awards
------

The Chandrayaan-3 mission has received several awards and recognition, including:

* The Indian Space Research Organisation (ISRO) has been awarded the "Space Pioneer Award" by the International Astronautical Federation (IAF)
* The Chandrayaan-3 mission has been awarded the "Best Space Mission" award by the Asia-Pacific Satellite Communications Council (APSCC)

See also
--------

* Chandrayaan-1
* Chandrayaan-2
* Indian Space Research Organisation (ISRO)
* Lunar exploration
* Space exploration

Notes
-----

This article is a summary of the Chandrayaan-3 mission. For more information, please refer to the references below.

References
----------

This article does not include any references. For more information, please refer to the external links below.

External links
---------------

article:
Thunivu
================

Thunivu is a 2023 Indian Tamil-language action thriller film written and directed by H. Vinoth and produced by Zee Studios and Boney Kapoor under the banner of Bayview Projects LLP. The film stars Ajith Kumar, Manju Warrier, and Samuthirakani in the lead roles. Thunivu marks the third collaboration between Ajith Kumar and H. Vinoth after Nerkonda Paarvai and Valimai.

Plot
-----

Thunivu follows the story of a bank heist that takes a complex turn when the mastermind behind the heist, played by Ajith Kumar, gets caught up in a larger conspiracy. The film explores themes of loyalty, betrayal, and redemption as the protagonist navigates through a web of corruption and deceit.

As the story unfolds, it becomes clear that the bank heist is just a small part of a larger scheme to plunder the wealth of the rich and powerful. The protagonist, a skilled thief, must use his wits and cunning to outsmart his enemies and stay one step ahead of the law.

Throughout the film, the protagonist's character is revealed through a series of flashbacks and conversations with other characters. His backstory is marked by tragedy and loss, which drives his motivations and actions throughout the story.

The film's climax features an intense showdown between the protagonist and the main antagonist, played by Samuthirakani. The action-packed sequence is filled with twists and turns, keeping the audience on the edge of their seats until the very end.

Cast
-----

*   Ajith Kumar as the protagonist
*   Manju Warrier as a police officer
*   Samuthirakani as the main antagonist
*   John Kokken as a supporting character
*   Veera as a supporting character
*   Bagavathi Perumal as a supporting character

Production
------------

### Development

Thunivu was first announced in February 2022, with H. Vinoth set to direct and Ajith Kumar starring in the lead role. The film's script was written by H. Vinoth, who had previously collaborated with Ajith Kumar on Nerkonda Paarvai and Valimai.

Kabzaa is an upcoming Indian Kannada-language action drama film written and directed by R. Chandru. The film stars Upendra, Kiccha Sudeep, and Shriya Saran in lead roles. Kabzaa is a period drama set in the 1940s and follows the story of a powerful underworld don.

#Plot

The film is set in the 1940s and revolves around the story of Arkeshwara, a powerful underworld don played by Upendra. The story begins with Arkeshwara, a small-time thief, who rises to become a powerful don in the underworld. He becomes a threat to the existing dons and the police department. Kiccha Sudeep plays the role of Bhargav Bakshi, a police officer who is determined to take down Arkeshwara. Shriya Saran plays the role of Madhumathi, a journalist who gets caught up in the conflict between Arkeshwara and Bhargav.

As the story unfolds, Arkeshwara's rise to power is depicted, and his confrontation with Bhargav and the police department forms the crux of the story. article:
2023 Liverpool City Council Election

The 2023 Liverpool City Council election took place on 4 May 2023 to elect members of Liverpool City Council. The election was held on the same day as other local elections in England.

# Candidates

A total of 126 candidates stood in the election, representing various political parties and independents. The Labour Party fielded candidates in all 30 wards, while the Liberal Democrats and Green Party also contested every ward. The Conservative Party fielded candidates in 24 wards, and the Liverpool Liberal Party stood in 4 wards. Additionally, there were several independent candidates.

# Council Composition

Prior to the election, the composition of the council was:

* Labour: 72 seats
* Liberal Democrats: 5 seats
* Green Party: 2 seats
* Independent: 2 seats

# Retiring Councillors (old wards)

Several councillors did not seek re-election, including:

* Councillor Richard Kemp (Liberal Democrat, Church ward)
* Councillor Erica Kemp (Liberal Democrat, Church ward)
* Councillor Steve Radford (Liberal, Tuebrook and Stoneycroft ward)
* Councillor Jeremy Wolff (Green, St Michael's ward)

# Results Summary

The election resulted in the Labour Party maintaining its majority on the council, winning 68 seats. The Liberal Democrats gained 2 seats and won a total of 7 seats. The Green Party won 4 seats, and the Conservative Party won 1 seat. There were no independent councillors elected.

# Voter Photo ID

This election was the first in Liverpool to require voters to show photo identification at polling stations. The requirement was introduced by the government as part of the Elections Act 2022. The majority of voters were able to produce the required ID, but some reported difficulties.

article:
Tartus
================

Tartus is a city located on the Mediterranean coast of Syria, approximately 220 kilometers northwest of Damascus. It is the capital of the Tartus Governorate and the second-largest port city in the country. With a rich history dating back to the Phoenician era, Tartus has been an important center of trade, culture, and commerce in the region.

Etymology
------------

The name "Tartus" is derived from the Phoenician word "Antaradus," which refers to the island of Arwad, located just off the coast of the city. Over time, the name evolved into "Tartus," which has been used since the Byzantine era.

History
---------

### Phoenician Antaradus

The area of Tartus has been inhabited since the Phoenician era, with Antaradus being an important center of trade and commerce. The city was founded on an island in the early 3rd century BC and was later connected to the mainland by a causeway. Antaradus was a major hub for the Phoenician trade network, with merchants trading goods such as purple dye, glass, and metals.

### Greco-Roman and Byzantine era

Following the conquest of the Phoenicians by Alexander the Great, Tartus came under Greek rule. The city flourished during this period, with the construction of temples, theaters, and other public buildings. With the rise of the Roman Empire, Tartus became an important center of trade and commerce, with merchants trading goods such as grain, wine, and olive oil. During the Byzantine era, Tartus was an important center of Christianity, with the city being the seat of a bishopric.

### Early Islamic era

In 636 AD, Tartus was conquered by the Arab armies of Caliph Umar. The city became an important center of Islamic culture and learning, with the establishment of mosques, madrasas, and other Islamic institutions. During this period, Tartus was also an important center of trade and commerce, with merchants trading goods such as textiles, spices, and metals.

### Crusades

In 1102, Tartus was captured by the Crusaders, who established a Latin bishopric in the city. The Crusaders fortified the city with walls and towers, and Tartus became an important base for their military campaigns in the region. In 1188, the city was recaptured by the Ayyubid dynasty, led by Saladin.

### Ottoman era

In 1517, Tartus was conquered by the Ottoman Empire, which ruled the city for nearly 400 years. During this period, Tartus was an important center of trade and commerce, with merchants trading goods such as cotton, silk, and spices. The city was also an important center of Ottoman culture and learning, with the establishment of mosques, madrasas, and other Islamic institutions.

### Modern era

In 1918, Tartus was occupied by French forces, which established a mandate over Syria. In 1946, Syria gained independence, and Tartus became an important center of government and administration. During the 1960s and 1970s, the city underwent significant development, with the construction of new infrastructure, including roads, bridges, and buildings.

Geography
------------

Tartus is located on the Mediterranean coast of Syria, approximately 220 kilometers northwest of Damascus. The city is situated on a small peninsula, with the Mediterranean Sea to the west and the Syrian mountains to the east. The city has a total area of approximately 29 square kilometers.

### Climate

Tartus has a Mediterranean climate, with warm summers and mild winters. The average temperature in January, the coldest month, is 12°C, while the average temperature in August, the warmest month, is 28°C. The city receives an average annual rainfall of approximately 900 mm.

Economy
----------

### Industry and navy

Tartus is an important center of industry and manufacturing, with a range of sectors, including textiles, food processing, and construction materials. The city is also home to a major naval base, which is an important center of maritime trade and commerce.

### Tourism

Tartus is a popular tourist destination, with a range of attractions, including beaches, historic sites, and cultural institutions. The city is also an important center of ecotourism, with a range of natural attractions, including the Syrian mountains and the Mediterranean coast.

### Russian naval base

article:
Batang Quiapo (TV series)

Batang Quiapo is a Philippine television drama series broadcast by Kapamilya Channel. The series premiered on February 13, 2023, and is currently ongoing. It is produced by Star Creatives and stars Coco Martin, Lovi Poe, and Charo Santos-Concio.

# Plot

The series revolves around the story of a young boy named Tanggol, who grows up in the streets of Quiapo, Manila. Tanggol, played by Coco Martin, is a kind-hearted and determined individual who dreams of a better life for himself and his community. He becomes embroiled in a world of crime and corruption, but his strong sense of justice and compassion ultimately lead him to become a force for good in the city.

Throughout the series, Tanggol faces numerous challenges and obstacles as he navigates the complexities of life in Quiapo. He must confront rival gangs, corrupt government officials, and personal struggles, all while maintaining his commitment to his community and his values.

# Cast and characters

## Present

* Coco Martin as Tanggol
* Lovi Poe as Monica
* Charo Santos-Concio as Lola Mina
* Christopher de Leon as Don Emilio
* Lito Lapid as Don Julio
* Irma Adlawan as Aling Saling
* Malou de Guzman as Aling Pacing
* PJ Endrinal as Bong
* Mark Lapid as Tatay Berto
* Shaina Magdayao as Tisay

## Former

* Baron Geisler as Tatay Intsik
* Soliman Cruz as Mang Tibo
* Leo Martinez as Don Gusting
* Smokey Manaloto as Bokbok
* Negi as Taba
* Dindo Arroyo as Tatay Peping

# Episodes

The series premiered on February 13, 2023, and has been airing new episodes every Monday to Friday at 8:00 PM on Kapamilya Channel. As of March 2023, the series has aired over 30 episodes.

# Production

## Development

The series was first announced in October 2022, with Coco Martin and Lovi Poe confirmed as the lead stars. The show was created by Star Creatives, the same production team behind the hit series Ang Probinsyano.

## Casting

Casting for the series began in November 2022, with several actors and actresses joining the show. Charo Santos-Concio was cast as Lola Mina, a wise and compassionate elder in the community. Christopher de Leon and Lito Lapid were also cast as rival gang leaders.

## Filming

Filming for the series began in December 2022, with several locations in Manila and surrounding areas used for filming. The show's production team has been praised for its use of authentic locations and its commitment to showcasing the beauty and culture of Quiapo.

# Broadcast

The series premiered on February 13, 2023, on Kapamilya Channel, with new episodes airing every Monday to Friday at 8:00 PM. The show is also available to stream on the Kapamilya Online Live YouTube channel.

# Soundtrack

The show's soundtrack features several original songs, including the theme song "Batang Quiapo" performed by Coco Martin. Other artists who have contributed to the soundtrack include Regine Velasquez, Erik Santos, and Angeline Quinto.

# Reception

## Ratings

The series has been a ratings success, with its premiere episode attracting over 2 million viewers. The show has consistently ranked as one of the top-rated programs in the Philippines.

## Online viewership

The show has also been a success online, with its YouTube channel gaining over 1 million subscribers in just a few weeks. The show's episodes have been viewed millions of times on YouTube and other online platforms.

## Controversy

### Muslim stereotype controversy

The show has faced controversy over its portrayal of Muslim characters, with some critics accusing the show of perpetuating stereotypes. The show's production team has apologized for any offense caused and has promised to be more sensitive in its portrayal of Muslim characters in the future.

# Accolades

The series has received several awards and nominations, including a nomination for Best Drama Series at the 2023 PMPC Star Awards for Television.

# Legacy

Batang Quiapo has been praised for its portrayal of the struggles and triumphs of the Filipino people. The show has also been credited with showcasing the beauty and culture of Quiapo, a historic district in Manila.

# Notes

The series is available to stream on the Kapamilya Online Live YouTube channel and on the iWantTFC app.

* Star Creatives

The 2022–23 season was the 123rd season in the history of FC Barcelona and their 92nd consecutive season in the top flight of Spanish football. The season covered the period from 1 July 2022 to 30 June 2023.

#Kits

The 2022–23 La Liga season began on 13 August 2022, with FC Barcelona hosting Rayo Vallecano at the Camp Nou. The match ended in a 0-0 draw. The team's first win of the season came on 21 August, with a 4-1 victory over Real Sociedad.

##September

FC Barcelona continued their good form in September, with wins over Sevilla FC, Real Betis, and Elche CF. The team also began their UEFA Champions League campaign, with a 0-0 draw against Viktoria Plzeň.

##October

##November

The team's form improved in November, with wins over Almería and Osasuna. FC Barcelona also advanced to the knockout stage of the UEFA Champions League, with a 4-2 win over Viktoria Plzeň.

##May

article:
2023–2024 Manipur violence

The 2023–2024 Manipur violence refers to a series of clashes, riots, and armed conflicts that have taken place in the Indian state of Manipur since May 2023. The violence has resulted in significant loss of life, displacement of people, and widespread destruction of property.

#Background

##Scheduled Tribe status for Meitei

The demand for Scheduled Tribe (ST) status for the Meitei community, the majority ethnic group in Manipur, has been a contentious issue for several years. The Meitei community has been seeking ST status, which they believe would provide them with greater protection and benefits under the Indian Constitution. However, this demand has been opposed by several other ethnic groups in the state, who fear that it would lead to the Meitei community dominating the state's politics and economy.

##Political background

Manipur has a complex and sensitive political landscape, with several ethnic groups vying for power and influence. The state has a long history of insurgency and militancy, with several armed groups operating in the region. The state government has struggled to maintain law and order, and the situation has been further complicated by the presence of several non-state actors, including armed groups and civil society organizations.

##Refugees from Myanmar

The influx of refugees from Myanmar, particularly the Chin community, has added to the complexity of the situation in Manipur. Many of these refugees have settled in the state, leading to tensions with the local population. The state government has struggled to provide adequate support and services to these refugees, leading to further social and economic tensions.

##International factors

The situation in Manipur has also been influenced by international factors, particularly the situation in Myanmar. The ongoing conflict in Myanmar has led to a significant influx of refugees into Manipur, putting pressure on the state's resources and infrastructure. Additionally, the state's proximity to the international border has made it vulnerable to cross-border militant activities.

#Antecedents

The violence in Manipur has its roots in a series of events that took place in the months leading up to May 2023. Tensions had been building between the Meitei community and other ethnic groups in the state, particularly the Kuki and Naga communities. The demand for ST status for the Meitei community had been gaining momentum, and several other ethnic groups had begun to mobilize against it.

In April 2023, a series of clashes took place between Meitei and Kuki groups in several parts of the state, resulting in several injuries and deaths. The state government had imposed curfew in several areas, but the situation remained tense.

#Overview

##Initial riots

On May 3, 2023, a series of riots broke out in several parts of Manipur, particularly in the Imphal Valley. The riots were sparked by a clash between Meitei and Kuki groups, and quickly spread to other parts of the state. Several buildings and vehicles were set on fire, and several people were injured.

##Government response

The state government responded quickly to the violence, imposing curfew in several areas and deploying security forces to affected regions. However, the situation remained volatile, with several clashes taking place between security forces and rioters.

##Recurrent violence

Despite the efforts of the state government, the violence continued to recur in several parts of the state. Several armed groups, including the Kuki National Organisation (KNO) and the United Naga Council (UNC), became involved in the violence, leading to further escalation.

##Warring groups

Several warring groups have been involved in the violence, including the Meitei, Kuki, and Naga communities. The situation has been further complicated by the presence of several non-state actors, including armed groups and civil society organizations.

##Casualties and victims

The violence has resulted in significant loss of life, with several hundred people killed or injured. Several thousand people have been displaced, and widespread destruction of property has taken place.

#Supreme Court proceedings

The Supreme Court of India has taken suo moto cognizance of the violence in Manipur, and has ordered the state government to take immediate action to restore law and order. The court has also ordered the state government to provide adequate compensation to victims of the violence.

#Reactions

The violence in Manipur has sparked widespread condemnation from across the country. Several civil society organizations and human rights groups have criticized the state government for its handling of the situation, and have called for greater action to protect the rights of marginalized communities.

#Media coverage

The violence in Manipur has received widespread media coverage, both nationally and internationally. Several news organizations have reported on the violence, highlighting the complexity of the situation and the need for greater action to restore peace and stability.

article:
The Maiden in the Tower
==========================

The Maiden in the Tower (Jungfrun i tornet) is an opera in one act by Jean Sibelius, composed in 1896. The libretto, written by Rafael Hertzberg, is based on a Swedish ballad of the same name. The opera premiered in 1896 but was withdrawn by the composer after only a few performances, and it remained largely forgotten until its posthumous revival in the 1980s.

History
--------

### Composition

The Maiden in the Tower was composed in 1896, during a period of intense creative activity for Sibelius. The opera was written quickly, with the composer working on the score in just a few weeks. The libretto, written by Rafael Hertzberg, is based on a traditional Swedish ballad of the same name, which tells the story of a young woman imprisoned in a tower by her mother.

### Premiere

The Maiden in the Tower premiered on November 7, 1896, at the Royal Swedish Opera in Stockholm. The production was directed by August Lindberg, and the title role was sung by soprano Emmy Achté. The premiere was not a success, with many critics finding the opera's music and libretto to be dull and unengaging.

### Withdrawal and suppression

Despite the initial failure of the premiere, The Maiden in the Tower was performed a few more times in the following years. However, Sibelius eventually withdrew the opera from circulation, and it was not performed again during his lifetime. The composer's decision to withdraw the opera was likely due to his own dissatisfaction with the work, as well as the negative reception it received from critics and audiences.

### Posthumous revival

The Maiden in the Tower was revived in the 1980s, more than 70 years after its premiere. The opera was performed in a number of productions throughout Europe and North America, and it has since been recognized as a significant work in Sibelius's oeuvre. The posthumous revival of The Maiden in the Tower has been attributed to a growing interest in Sibelius's early works, as well as a reevaluation of the opera's music and libretto.

Structure and roles
-------------------

The Maiden in the Tower is an opera in one act, with a total of five roles:

* The Maiden: soprano
* The Mother: mezzo-soprano
* The Lover: tenor
* The Servant: baritone
* The Herald: bass

Synopsis
--------

The opera takes place in a medieval castle, where the Maiden is imprisoned in a tower by her mother. The Maiden's lover, a knight, arrives at the castle and attempts to rescue her. However, the Mother discovers their plan and imprisons the Lover in the tower as well. The Servant, who is sympathetic to the lovers, helps them to escape, and they are reunited in the final scene.

Music
------

The music of The Maiden in the Tower is characterized by its use of leitmotifs, which were a common feature of Sibelius's operas. The opera's score also features a number of folk-inspired melodies, which were influenced by Sibelius's interest in traditional Finnish music. The opera's orchestration is notable for its use of a large orchestra, which includes a number of unusual instruments, such as the contrabassoon and the English horn.

Context and analysis
---------------------

### The plot as allegory

The plot of The Maiden in the Tower has been interpreted as an allegory for the struggle for Finnish independence. The Maiden, who is imprisoned in the tower by her mother, represents the Finnish people, who were subject to Russian rule at the time the opera was written. The Lover, who attempts to rescue the Maiden, represents the Finnish nationalist movement, which was seeking to free Finland from Russian control.

### Opera and Finland's language strife

The Maiden in the Tower was written during a period of intense language strife in Finland, which was a Grand Duchy of Russia at the time. The opera's libretto, which was written in Swedish, was seen as a symbol of the Swedish-speaking elite, who dominated Finnish society and politics. However, the opera's music, which was influenced by traditional Finnish folk melodies, was seen as a expression of Finnish nationalism.

### Later opinions of Sibelius's music

The Maiden in the Tower was initially received negatively by critics and audiences, who found the opera's music and libretto to be dull and unengaging. However, in the years following its premiere, Sibelius's music became increasingly popular, and he was recognized as one of the leading composers of his generation. The posthumous revival of The Maiden in the Tower has been attributed to a growing interest in Sibelius's early works, as well as a reevaluation of the opera's music and libretto.

### Reasons for post-1981 neglect

Despite its posthumous revival, The Maiden in the Tower has been relatively neglected in recent years. The opera's neglect has been attributed to a number of factors, including its limited availability on recording and its perceived lack of dramatic interest. However, the opera's music and libretto continue to be recognized as significant works in Sibelius's oeuvre, and it remains an important part of the composer's legacy.

article:
Chip 'n Dale: Rescue Rangers (film)

Chip 'n Dale: Rescue Rangers is a 2022 American live-action/animated adventure comedy film directed by Akiva Schaffer and written by Dan Gregor and Doug Mand. The film is based on the 1989 animated television series of the same name and serves as a sequel to the original series.

# Plot

The film takes place in the present day, with Chip 'n Dale living separate lives. Chip (voiced by John Mulaney) is a successful computer chip salesman, while Dale (voiced by Andy Samberg) works as a social media influencer. However, when they are reunited at a mutual friend's funeral, they are drawn back into their old Rescue Rangers routine.

The duo teams up with a new generation of Rescue Rangers, including Ellie Steckler (KiKi Layne), a human who helps them navigate the modern world. Together, they embark on a mission to rescue their friend, Fat Cat (Eric Stonestreet), who has been kidnapped by a group of villains.

As they navigate through the city, Chip and Dale face various obstacles, including a series of wacky misadventures and run-ins with their old nemesis, Fat Cat's owner, Norton Nimnul (Will Arnett). Along the way, they learn to put aside their differences and work together to save their friend.

# Cast

* John Mulaney as the voice of Chip
* Andy Samberg as the voice of Dale
* KiKi Layne as Ellie Steckler
* Eric Stonestreet as the voice of Fat Cat
* Will Arnett as the voice of Norton Nimnul
* Keegan-Michael Key as the voice of Bjornson the Cheesemonger
* Tawny Newsome as the voice of Zipper
* J.K. Simmons as the voice of Captain Putty
* Chris Parnell as the voice of Dave
* Alan Oppenheimer as the voice of Orson

# Production

## Development and pre-production

Development on Chip 'n Dale: Rescue Rangers began in 2014, with Robert Zemeckis set to direct and produce the film. However, in 2018, it was announced that Akiva Schaffer would be taking over as director, with Dan Gregor and Doug Mand set to write the screenplay.

The film's script was influenced by the original animated series, with the writers drawing inspiration from the show's blend of humor and action. The story was also updated to reflect modern themes and technology.

## Casting

Z (military symbol)
=====================

The letter "Z" has been used as a military symbol in various contexts, particularly in recent years. The origins and meaning of this symbol are complex and multifaceted, and its use has been the subject of controversy and debate.

Military Use
------------

### Description

The "Z" symbol is often displayed on military equipment, vehicles, and uniforms. It is typically rendered in a bold, white, or yellow font on a black or green background. In some cases, the symbol may be accompanied by other markings or insignia.

### Purpose

The primary purpose of the "Z" symbol is to identify military units or vehicles as belonging to a specific force or faction. In some cases, the symbol may be used to signify a particular mission or operation. The use of the "Z" symbol can also serve as a form of psychological warfare, intended to intimidate or demoralize enemy forces.

### Naming

The origins of the "Z" symbol are unclear, and it is not certain how it came to be associated with military forces. Some theories suggest that the symbol may have been chosen for its simplicity and ease of recognition, while others propose that it may have been inspired by the Cyrillic letter "Z" (З), which is similar in appearance to the Latin letter "Z".

### Other

#### Business

The 2023 New South Wales state election was held on [date] to elect the 58th Parliament of New South Wales, including all 93 seats in the Legislative Assembly and 21 of the 42 seats in the Legislative Council. The election was conducted by the New South Wales Electoral Commission.

# Background

## Change of premiership, resignations and minority government

Dominic Perrottet succeeded her as Premier and Liberal leader. However, the Coalition's majority in the Legislative Assembly was reduced to one seat following the resignation of several MPs, including former Deputy Premier John Barilaro. The Coalition was forced to govern in minority, relying on the support of independents to pass legislation.

## Possibility of a hung parliament

article:
Michelle Yeoh
================

Tan Sri Dato' Seri Michelle Yeoh Choo-kheng is a Malaysian actress who rose to international fame for her starring roles in a succession of action films. Regarded as one of the most successful Hong Kong action heroines of all time, Yeoh has also gained international recognition for her dramatic roles in films like "Crouching Tiger, Hidden Dragon" and "Crazy Rich Asians". With a career spanning over three decades, Yeoh has solidified her position as a leading lady in both Eastern and Western cinema.

Early life and education
------------------------

Michelle Yeoh was born on August 6, 1962, in Ipoh, Perak, Malaysia. Her father, Yeoh Kian Teik, was a lawyer and politician, and her mother, Janet Yeoh, was a housewife. Yeoh's early life was marked by a blend of Chinese and Malaysian cultures, which would later influence her career choices. She began taking ballet lessons at the age of four and later attended the Convent of the Holy Infant Jesus in Ipoh. In 1980, Yeoh moved to London to study ballet at the Royal Academy of Dance.

Career
--------

### Early career and first retirement (1983–1991)

Yeoh's entry into the entertainment industry began with her participation in the Miss Malaysia World pageant in 1983, which she won. This victory led to her being crowned Miss World Malaysia and representing Malaysia at the Miss World pageant in London. Although she did not win the international title, Yeoh's exposure at the pageant caught the attention of a Hong Kong film producer, who offered her a film contract. Yeoh made her film debut in 1983 with the action-comedy "The Owl vs. Dumbo" and went on to star in a string of successful films throughout the 1980s, including "Twinkle, Twinkle, Lucky Stars" and "Magnificent Warriors".

In 1987, Yeoh married Hong Kong businessman Dickson Poon and announced her retirement from acting. However, the marriage was short-lived, and the couple divorced in 1992.

### Return as an action star (1992–2001)

Yeoh's return to acting in 1992 marked the beginning of a new era in her career. She began taking on more action-oriented roles, showcasing her physical abilities and martial arts skills. Films like "Police Story 3: Supercop" and "The Heroic Trio" solidified Yeoh's status as a leading action heroine in Hong Kong cinema. Her success in the action genre also led to opportunities in Hollywood, with roles in films like "Tomorrow Never Dies" and "Enter the Eagles".

### Career fluctuations (2002–2016)

In the early 2000s, Yeoh's career experienced a period of fluctuation. She continued to work in Hong Kong cinema, but her roles became less frequent and less prominent. Yeoh also faced increased competition from younger actresses, which led to a decline in her popularity. However, she continued to work in television and film, taking on a mix of dramatic and action-oriented roles.

In 2008, Yeoh starred in the critically acclaimed film "Babylon A.D.", which marked a turning point in her career. The film's success led to increased recognition for Yeoh, and she began to take on more prominent roles in international productions.

### Supporting roles (2017–2020)

In the late 2010s, Yeoh began to focus on supporting roles in film and television. She appeared in films like "Crazy Rich Asians" and "Star Trek: Discovery", which showcased her ability to play complex and nuanced characters. Yeoh's performances in these roles earned her critical acclaim and recognition within the industry.

### Award success (2021–present)

In 2021, Yeoh starred in the film "Everything Everywhere All at Once", which premiered at the Sundance Film Festival. The film's success led to widespread critical acclaim for Yeoh, with many praising her performance as one of the best of her career. Yeoh went on to win several awards for her performance, including the Academy Award for Best Actress.

Activism
----------

Throughout her career, Yeoh has been involved in various charitable and philanthropic efforts. In 2008, she was appointed as a Goodwill Ambassador for the United Nations Development Programme, focusing on issues related to poverty and inequality. Yeoh has also been involved in several environmental initiatives, including the conservation of wildlife and the protection of natural habitats.

Personal life
-------------

Yeoh has been married to French businessman Jean Todt since 2004. The couple has no children together, but Todt has two children from a previous relationship. Yeoh is a practicing Buddhist and has stated that her faith has had a significant impact on her life and career.

Filmography
------------

2023 Masters (snooker)

The 2023 Masters was a professional non-ranking snooker tournament that took place from January 8 to 15, 2023, at the Alexandra Palace in London, England. The 49th edition of the Masters, it was the second of three Triple Crown events in the 2022-2023 season, following the UK Championship and preceding the World Snooker Championship.

# Overview

The Masters is one of the most prestigious tournaments in professional snooker, with a long history dating back to 1975. The event features the top 16 players in the world rankings, competing in a knockout format. The tournament has a rich history, with many legendary players having lifted the trophy, including Ronnie O'Sullivan, John Higgins, and Stephen Hendry.

## Participants

The 2023 Masters featured the top 16 players in the world rankings, including defending champion Neil Robertson, world number one Mark Selby, and crowd favorite Ronnie O'Sullivan. The field also included several young and up-and-coming players, such as Zhao Xintong and Luca Brecel, who were looking to make a name for themselves in the snooker world.

## Prize money

The total prize money for the 2023 Masters was £725,000, with the winner receiving £210,000. The runner-up received £105,000, while the losing semi-finalists received £60,000 each.

# Summary

The 2023 Masters was a closely contested tournament, with several high-quality matches played throughout the event.

## First round

The first round saw several close matches, with top players struggling to assert their dominance. Defending champion Neil Robertson edged out Barry Hawkins 6-4, while Mark Selby defeated Shaun Murphy 6-5. Ronnie O'Sullivan, however, was in imperious form, thrashing Jack Lisowski 6-1.

## Quarter-finals

The quarter-finals saw several upsets, with lower-ranked players causing shocks against more established opponents. Luca Brecel defeated Mark Selby 6-4, while Zhao Xintong edged out Neil Robertson 6-5. Ronnie O'Sullivan, however, continued his dominant form, thrashing Stuart Bingham 6-2.

## Semi-finals

The semi-finals saw two closely contested matches, with both matches going to a deciding frame. Luca Brecel edged out Zhao Xintong 6-5, while Ronnie O'Sullivan defeated Judd Trump 6-5.

## Final

The final saw Ronnie O'Sullivan face Luca Brecel, with the crowd favorite looking to win his eighth Masters title. O'Sullivan was in dominant form, winning the match 10-6. The victory marked O'Sullivan's 21st Triple Crown title, cementing his status as one of the greatest players in snooker history.

**Jim Brown**

James Nathaniel Brown, known professionally as Jim Brown, was an American football player, actor, and social activist. He is widely regarded as one of the greatest football players of all time, and his impressive athletic career was followed by a successful acting career and a commitment to civil rights activism.

**Early life**

Jim Brown was born on February 17, 1936, in St. Simons, Georgia, to Theresa and Swinton Brown. His family moved to Long Island, New York, when he was a young child, and he grew up in the town of Manhasset. Brown's early life was marked by athletic achievement, and he was a standout player in multiple sports at Manhasset High School. He was particularly talented in football, lacrosse, and track and field, and was named All-American in football in 1953.

**College career**

Brown attended Syracuse University, where he played football, lacrosse, and basketball. He was a dominant force on the football field, leading the Syracuse Orange to a national championship in 1956 and setting multiple school records for rushing and scoring. Brown's impressive college career earned him a place in the College Football Hall of Fame in 1995.

**Professional career**

The Cleveland Browns selected Brown in the first round of the 1957 NFL Draft, and he quickly became one of the league's top players. Over the course of his nine-year career, Brown rushed for 12,312 yards and scored 126 touchdowns, leading the Browns to four NFL championships. He was named the NFL's Most Valuable Player four times and was a nine-time Pro Bowl selection. Brown's impressive statistics and dominant play earned him a place in the Pro Football Hall of Fame in 1971.

**Acting career**

## Early films

Brown began his acting career in the early 1960s, appearing in small roles in films such as "Rio Conchos" (1964) and "The Dirty Dozen" (1967). He quickly gained recognition for his charismatic on-screen presence and his ability to play complex, nuanced characters.

## Leading man

article:
2023 Hawaii Wildfires

The 2023 Hawaii wildfires were a series of devastating wildfires that burned across the state of Hawaii in August 2023. The fires were fueled by hot and dry weather conditions, strong winds, and dry vegetation, and resulted in significant damage, loss of life, and displacement of residents.

**Background**

### Wildfire risk

Hawaii is considered a high-risk state for wildfires due to its dry climate, rugged terrain, and strong winds. The state's unique geography, with its mountainous islands and coastal areas, creates a variety of ecosystems that are prone to wildfires. The risk of wildfires in Hawaii is further exacerbated by the presence of invasive plant species, such as fountain grass and christmas berry, which can fuel fires and spread quickly.

### Weather factors

The weather conditions in August 2023 were ideal for wildfires. A high-pressure system brought hot and dry air to the islands, with temperatures soaring above 90°F (32°C) and humidity levels dropping below 20%. Strong winds, gusting up to 50 mph (80 km/h), also contributed to the spread of the fires.

**List of wildfires**

Here is a list of some of the major wildfires that burned in Hawaii in 2023:

* Kula Fire (Maui)
* Lahaina Fire (Maui)
* Pūlehu-Kīhei Fire (Maui)
* Mauna Loa Fire (Hawaiʻi Island)
* North Shore Fire (Oʻahu)

**Timeline**

### Maui

#### Kula

The Kula Fire started on August 8, 2023, in the Kula region of Maui. The fire quickly spread due to strong winds and dry vegetation, burning over 1,000 acres of land. Residents in the area were forced to evacuate, and several homes were destroyed.

#### Lahaina

The Lahaina Fire started on August 10, 2023, in the Lahaina region of Maui. The fire burned over 500 acres of land, forcing the evacuation of several hundred residents. The fire also damaged several businesses and historic buildings in the area.

#### Pūlehu-Kīhei

The Pūlehu-Kīhei Fire started on August 11, 2023, in the Pūlehu-Kīhei region of Maui. The fire burned over 2,000 acres of land, forcing the evacuation of several thousand residents. The fire also damaged several homes and businesses in the area.

#### Other fires

Several other fires burned on Maui, including the Olinda Fire, the Makawao Fire, and the Haliimaile Fire. These fires burned over 1,000 acres of land and forced the evacuation of several hundred residents.

### Hawaiʻi Island

The Mauna Loa Fire started on August 12, 2023, on the Big Island of Hawaiʻi. The fire burned over 5,000 acres of land, forcing the evacuation of several hundred residents. The fire also damaged several homes and businesses in the area.

### Oʻahu

The North Shore Fire started on August 14, 2023, on the North Shore of Oʻahu. The fire burned over 1,000 acres of land, forcing the evacuation of several hundred residents. The fire also damaged several homes and businesses in the area.

**Impact**

### Casualties

The 2023 Hawaii wildfires resulted in several fatalities and injuries. Several residents were forced to evacuate their homes, and many were left without power or access to basic necessities.

### Damage

The fires caused significant damage to homes, businesses, and infrastructure. Several historic buildings and landmarks were also damaged or destroyed.

### Environment

The fires had a significant impact on the environment, with many acres of land burned and several endangered species affected.

### Evacuations

Several thousand residents were forced to evacuate their homes due to the fires. Many were left without power or access to basic necessities.

### Wildlife and pets

Many animals, including pets and wildlife, were affected by the fires. Several animal shelters were set up to care for displaced animals.

**Legal proceedings**

Several lawsuits were filed against the state and federal governments, as well as private companies, for their role in the fires. The lawsuits alleged negligence and failure to properly prepare for and respond to the fires.

**Response**

### Federal government

The federal government provided assistance to the state of Hawaii, including funding and personnel. The Federal Emergency Management Agency (FEMA) was activated to provide support to affected residents.

### State government

The state government of Hawaii responded quickly to the fires, with the governor declaring a state of emergency. The state provided funding and personnel to support affected residents.

### International assistance

Several countries provided assistance to Hawaii, including:

#### Japan

Japan provided funding and personnel to support affected residents.

#### South Korea

South Korea provided funding and personnel to support affected residents.

#### Taiwan

Taiwan provided funding and personnel to support affected residents.

#### Hungary

Hungary provided funding and personnel to support affected residents.

### Fundraising and donations

Several fundraising campaigns were set up to support affected residents, with many individuals and organizations donating money and supplies.

### Concerns about preparedness

The 2023 Hawaii wildfires raised concerns about the state's preparedness for natural disasters. Many residents and officials questioned whether the state was adequately prepared for the fires, and whether more could have been done to prevent them.

#### New warning programs

In response to the fires, the state of Hawaii implemented new warning programs to alert residents of potential natural disasters. The programs included text message alerts and social media updates.

### Conspiracy theories

Several conspiracy theories emerged in the aftermath of the fires, with some individuals claiming that the fires were intentionally set or that the government was hiding information about the cause of the fires.

article:
July 2022 United Kingdom government crisis

The July 2022 United Kingdom government crisis was a major political crisis that led to the resignation of Boris Johnson as Prime Minister of the United Kingdom and the collapse of his government. The crisis was sparked by a series of scandals and controversies surrounding Johnson's leadership, culminating in a wave of resignations by senior government ministers.

Background

Boris Johnson had been Prime Minister since July 2019, when he succeeded Theresa May as leader of the Conservative Party. During his tenure, Johnson's government was marked by controversy and scandal, including the COVID-19 pandemic, Brexit, and allegations of impropriety and corruption. Despite these challenges, Johnson's government had maintained a relatively stable majority in the House of Commons, thanks in part to the support of his own party and the Democratic Unionist Party (DUP).

However, in the months leading up to the crisis, Johnson's popularity had begun to decline, and his government was facing growing criticism from within his own party and from opposition parties. The final straw came in early July 2022, when a series of scandals broke, including the resignation of Chancellor of the Exchequer Rishi Sunak and the revelation of a party held at 10 Downing Street during the COVID-19 lockdown.

Collapse of the government

The crisis began on July 5, 2022, when Chancellor of the Exchequer Rishi Sunak and Health Secretary Sajid Javid resigned from the government, citing a loss of confidence in Johnson's leadership. The resignations were followed by a wave of other departures, including those of several junior ministers and parliamentary private secretaries.

Support for Johnson

Despite the wave of resignations, Johnson initially maintained the support of his party and refused to step down. However, as the crisis deepened, it became increasingly clear that his position was untenable. On July 7, 2022, Johnson's newly appointed Chancellor, Nadhim Zahawi, publicly called for him to resign, and several other senior ministers followed suit.

Resignation of Boris Johnson

On July 7, 2022, Boris Johnson announced his resignation as leader of the Conservative Party and Prime Minister of the United Kingdom. In a statement outside 10 Downing Street, Johnson acknowledged that he had lost the support of his party and that it was time for him to step down.

Reactions

Domestic

The reaction to Johnson's resignation was mixed, with some commentators praising his achievements as Prime Minister, while others criticized his handling of the crisis. The opposition Labour Party welcomed the news, with leader Keir Starmer calling for a general election. The Liberal Democrats also called for an election, while the Scottish National Party (SNP) called for another independence referendum.

International

Internationally, the reaction to Johnson's resignation was largely neutral, with many world leaders expressing appreciation for his service as Prime Minister. The European Union's Commission President, Ursula von der Leyen, praised Johnson's commitment to the Brexit agreement, while the United States' President, Joe Biden, expressed appreciation for his partnership on global issues.

List of departures

The following is a list of senior government ministers and officials who resigned during the crisis:

* Rishi Sunak, Chancellor of the Exchequer
* Sajid Javid, Health Secretary
* Nadhim Zahawi, Chancellor of the Exchequer
* Grant Shapps, Transport Secretary
* Mark Spencer, Leader of the House of Commons
* Michelle Donelan, Education Secretary
* Chris Philp, Digital, Culture, Media and Sport Secretary
* Rachel Maclean, Minister for Safeguarding
* Mims Davies, Employment Minister
* Alex Chalk, Solicitor General

Destruction of the Kakhovka Dam

The Kakhovka Dam, a hydroelectric dam located on the Dnieper River in Ukraine, was destroyed on June 6, 2023, resulting in significant flooding and disruption to the surrounding region. The dam's destruction has had far-reaching consequences, affecting not only the local population but also the environment, military operations, and the economy.

#Background

The Kakhovka Dam was constructed in the 1950s as part of the Kakhovka Hydroelectric Power Plant, which was designed to provide hydroelectric power and irrigation for the surrounding agricultural region. The dam was located near the city of Nova Kakhovka, in the Kherson Oblast of Ukraine. The dam's reservoir, Lake Kakhovka, was an important source of water for irrigation, drinking water, and industrial use.

In 2014, following the Russian annexation of Crimea, the dam's operation was taken over by Russian-backed forces. Since then, the dam has been the subject of controversy, with Ukraine accusing Russia of using the dam as a tool for exerting control over the region's water supply.

#Destruction

On June 6, 2023, at approximately 02:50 local time, the Kakhovka Dam was destroyed, resulting in a massive release of water from the reservoir. The cause of the destruction is disputed, with Ukraine and Russia pointing fingers at each other. The destruction of the dam was reportedly caused by an explosion, which was captured on video by local residents.

#Responsibility

The question of responsibility for the destruction of the Kakhovka Dam remains a contentious issue. Ukraine has accused Russia of deliberately destroying the dam, while Russia has denied any involvement, suggesting that the destruction was caused by Ukrainian forces. The investigation into the incident is ongoing, and it is unclear at this time who will be held responsible.

#Legal responses
